The Chapter on the Great Being, the Elephant🔽The Perfection of Morality
The Story of the God of Dhamma
“Then again, when I was
a great-winged one, of great psychic power,
called the great spirit Dhamma,

analyzed: sabba loka anukampakaḥ  dasa kusala kamma pathe  samādapa intaḥ mahā jana
translated: compassionate to all the world.🔽I was encouraging the masses🔽in the ten ways of wholesome action;
I was wandering from village to village,
with my friends and retinue.

analyzed: pāpaḥ kadariyaḥ yakkhaḥ  dīpentaḥ dasa pāpake
translated: A wicked, stingy spirit,🔽extolling the ten unwholesome actions,
was wandering around here,
with his friends and retinue.
The one who spoke Dhamma and the one who spoke non-Dhamma,
we were both adversaries;
clashing yoke against yoke,
we were both on the same path.
A fierce quarrel was taking place
between the one of good and the one of bad;
for the sake of getting off the path,
a great battle was set up.
If I were to get angry here,
if I were to break my virtue,
I would make him and his retinue
become a dust heap.

analyzed: api ca aham sīla rakkhāya  nibbāpetvāna mānasa
translated: But rather, for the sake of protecting my virtue,🔽having cooled my mind,
having got off the path with my people,
I will give the path to the bad one.
As soon as he had stepped on the path,
and had brought his mind to tranquillity,
the earth opened up,
and immediately the wicked yakkha was swallowed up.”
The Story of Dhammadevaputta is the eighth.
